pages.text: No wonder this art was lost to time! Casting _Hexes is quite difficult, so I'll have to re-read my notes carefully.$(br2)I start casting a _Hex by pressing $(k:use) with a $(item)Staff/$ in my hand. A hexagonal grid of points will spring in front of my eyes. Then, I can click and drag between those points to draw a pattern, releasing the button when I am through with a pattern.

Once I'm done casting the spell, the grid will disappear as the _media I've bunched up is released. I can also press Escape if I want to quit early, if I don't mind a small mishap.$(br2)So what do I $(italic)do/$ with my staff? In short, there's a pipeline to follow:$(li)$(italic)Patterns/$ are matched to...$(li)$(italic)Actions/$, which manipulate...$(li)$(italic)The Stack/$, which consists of...$(li)$(italic)Iotas/$.

First, $(thing)patterns/$. As mentioned before, they're my means of interacting with and manipulating the _media around me. Certain patterns are associated with $(thing)actions/$. Actions are what actually $(italic)do/$ the magic; the _media is moved in particular ways by all patterns, and when it ends up doing something useful, we call it an action.$(br2)_Media is fickle; if I draw a pattern that is $(italic)not/$ a valid action, it usually causes a mishap.
It's interesting to note that the $(italic)direction/$ I draw a pattern in doesn't seem to matter at all. These two patterns both match to $(action)Mind's Reflection/$, for example.

A _Hex is cast via a sequence of (valid) actions. Each action might do one of a few things:$(li)Gather some information about the environment.$(li)Do some kind of operation on the gathered data, mathematic or otherwise. (These actions are called "spells.")$(li)Perform some magical effect, like summoning lightning or an explosion.$(li)And of course, a magical mishap due to a mistake.

When I start casting a _Hex, it creates an empty stack. Actions do what they do via manipulating that stack.$(br2)For example, $(l:patterns/basic#OpGetCaster)$(action)Mind's Reflection/$ will push a reference to $(italic)me/$, the caster, onto the stack. $(l:patterns/basic#OpentityPos)$(action)Compass Purification/$ will pop an entity reference and push its location.$(br2)So, casting them in that order would result in my position on the stack.

In many ways, it reminds me of the spells cast by the practitioners of the $(thing)Psionic/$ arts during the 1.12 Renaissance, headed by a certain master of mathematics and railguns. $(br2)If I find I am not quite sure what a stack is, I might want to read $(l:casting/stack)this entry on the subject$(/l).

Those pieces of information, like me and my position, are called $(thing)Iotas/$. There are several different types:$(li)Number (which some legends call a "double")$(li)Vector, a collection of three numbers representing a position, movement, or direction in the world$(li)Entity, like me or an animal$(li)Influence, a peculiar type that seems to represent various abstract ideas$(li)A pattern itself, used for crafting magic items and truly mind-boggling feats like $(italic)spells that cast other spells/$$(li)And a list of any of the above.

Of course, there's no such thing as a free lunch. All spells, and certain other actions, require _media as payment.$(br2)The best I can figure, a _Hex is a little bit like a plan of action presented to Nature. The _media is used to provide the arguments to back it up, so Nature will accept your plan and carry it out.

That aside, it doesn't seem like anyone has done much research on exactly how $(italic)much/$ any particular piece of amethyst is valued. The best I can tell, an $(item)Amethyst Shard/$ is worth about five $(item)Amethyst Dusts/$, and a $(item)Charged Amethyst Crystal/$ is worth about ten $(item)Amethyst Dusts/$.$(br2)Strangely enough, it seems like no other form of amethyst is suitable to be used in the casting of a _Hex. I suspect that whole blocks or crystals are too solid to be easily unraveled into _media.

It's worth noting that each action will consume the _media it needs individually, not all at once when the Hex finishes. Also, an action will always consume entire items. An action that only requires one $(item)Amethyst Dust/$'s worth of _media will consume an entire $(item)Charged Amethyst Crystal/$, if that's all that's present in my inventory.$(br2)So, it might be salient to $(italic)not/$ always use a Fortune pick when mining crystals so as not to waste _media...

I should also be careful to make sure I actually have enough Amethyst in my inventory. It seems Nature is $(italic)more/$ than happy to use my own mind as payment for a spell. The feeling is described as awful but strangely euphoric, an effervescent dissolution into light and energy... Perhaps this is why all the old practitioners of the art went mad. I can't imagine a constant abrading of one's mind is healthy.$(br2)In any case, I estimate my health at its prime can be converted into approximately one $(item)Charged Amethyst Crystal/$'s worth of mana before I die.

I have also found an amusing tidbit on why so many practitioners of magic in general seem to go mad, which I may like as some light and flavorful reading not canonical to my world.$(br2)$(italic)Content Warning: some body horror and suggestive elements./$
